awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: A New Coding Paradigm for Communication Over Broadcast Channels Using Nested Linear Codes: A Duality of Structure and Randomness
awd_abstract_narration:
In the recent past, several application scenarios have emerged that require large-scale deployment of communication network infrastructure such as packet-switched wireline networks, mobile cellular wireless networks, and distributed sensor networks. In this project, the problem of efficient communication of information in multiterminal systems, where a multiuser channel must be shared among several users in the network is addressed.  The new coding methods developed in this project shed light on intricate structural aspects of abstract groups. The development of efficient coding techniques has broad impact on the next generation of communication networks. 

In this project, the development of a unified framework to address a class of network communication problems based on new multiuser code ensembles constructed from nested linear codes is studied. In particular, the problem of transmission of information over general discrete memoryless broadcast channels is considered. This problem has received a great deal of attention in the last thirty years. This approach is then applied to  other multiuser channels such as the interference channel. For these problems, the average performance of nested linear code ensembles is strictly better than that of the standard unstructured code ensembles. The development of a  methodology to compute the performance limits of such coding schemes (which are  finite dimensional yet non-convex optimization problems) efficiently  with current technology is considered. This project also considers the development of practical constructions of codes with computationally efficient encoding and decoding algorithms and procedures. This is accomplished by putting additional sparsity constraints on the generator and parity-check matrices of these codes.

por.por_cntn:
This project addresses the fundamental issues regarding construction and management of heterogeneous communication networks. In particular, the issues regarding the development of efficient coding strategies in the physical layer of the network is addressed. This project provides an algebraic framework for such coding constructions. 
This framework answers the following questions. 
  
Firstly, how does one craft codes possessing algebraic closure properties, henceforth referred to as coset codes, to achieve optimal information theoretic performance of point to point networks. It maybe noted that to achieve optimal performance, codes must contain sufficient number of codewords typical with respect to a certain distribution. This will therefore involve identifying and sieving out codewords within coset codes meeting typicality requirements - an interplay of algebra and combinatorics. How does one achieve capacity of an arbitrary point-to-point channel if he or she is restricted to coset code?  These questions have been addressed in the project.
Secondly, how does one endow the various codes employed in a multi-terminal network with joint algebraic properties to enable their favorable interaction over the network. Indeed, it is the interaction of the various codes over a multi-terminal network that motivates the need to endow these codes with tightly coupled algebraic properties. Moreover, each code employed in a multi-terminal network has a specific structure and purpose. For example, channel codes employed for a broadcast network must possess subcodes (bins) that can be used for quantization, while on the other hand, codes employed for distributed source coding must possess subcodes (bins) whose codewords are spread apart. The question of which codes or subcodes must possess algebraic properties and how does one balance this requirement with the typicality requirements necessary to achieve optimal throughput has been addressed in the project. 

Thirdly, how does one analyze the info-theoretic performance of a coding technique that employs correlated codebooks possessing algebraic properties. The statistical independence of (i) codewords within a code and (ii) of the various codes employed plays an important role in simplifying the info-theoretic analysis of a random coding technique. The project has presented new mathematical tools that enable us to characterize the info-theoretic performance of a random coding technique wherein codes and codewords possessing tightly coupled algebraic properties are statistically correlated. In fact, these tools enable us to characterize the performance of the proposed coding technique over an arbitrary instance of the multi-terminal network considered
